body:
This looks like it isn't just the expansion, but also the extra code that is being created. e.g. compiling `regextest` with and without the static regex tests gives the following for `-Z time-passes` (with `-O`):

| pass | +static | -static |
| --: | --: | --: |
| expansion | 6.5 | 0.6 |
| resolution | 2.1 | 0.2 |
| type checking | 21.4 | 4.4 |
| LLVM passes | 109 | 16 |

It looks like this may just be essentially a function of the amount of code being generated, with not much scope for fixing other than "make rustc faster".
This issue has been moved to the regex repo: rust-lang/regex#27

I'm re-opening this after it was moved to rust-lang/regex because I think it is predominantly related to compile times of lots of code.

With that said, I'm also leaving this issue open in rust-lang/regex because the macro should probably generate a lot less code than it does today.

Updated. Code:

```rust
#![feature(plugin)]
#![allow(dead_code)]

#![plugin(regex_macros)]

extern crate regex;

#[cfg(short)]
fn short() {
    regex!("a");
}

#[cfg(medium)]
fn medium() {
    // 500
    regex!("");
}

#[cfg(long)]
fn long() {
    // 1000
    regex!("");
}

fn main() {}
```

Output:

```text
$ for x in short medium long; do echo $x; time cargo rustc -- --cfg $x -Z no-trans; done
short
   Compiling testingtesting v0.1.0 (file:///C:/Users/steve/tmp/testingtesting)
    Finished debug [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.34 secs

real    0m0.583s
user    0m0.000s
sys     0m0.015s

    Finished debug [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 3.21 secs

user    0m0.000s
sys     0m0.000s
long
   Compiling testingtesting v0.1.0 (file:///C:/Users/steve/tmp/testingtesting)
    Finished debug [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 11.4 secs

real    0m11.297s
user    0m0.000s
sys     0m0.015s
```

I agree with @huonw 's assessment:

> It looks like this may just be essentially a function of the amount of code being generated, with not much scope for fixing other than "make rustc faster".

In addition, `regex!` is much slower than `Regex::new`, which compiles in basically `0.53` seconds for all three variants.

As such, I'm gonna give this a close: in general, we should get faster, but this specific situation is pretty obscure and not particularly degenerate.
